description: Book Biwako Hanakaido in Kyoto Lake Biwa Onsen (Shiga) Located on a hill facing Lake Biwa, this onsen ryokan is 20-minute train ride from the Kyoto Station. After having undergone renovation in 2019, its fourth floor became an exclusive floor for guest rooms with private open-air onsen baths. You can also enjoy hot spring at the gender-segregated large public baths (with open-air baths) and a rental bath outside the rooms for private use. Kaiseki meals making use of Omi beef and fish from Lake Biwa are a feast for the eyes and the stomach.

description: Book Migiwatei Ochi Kochi in Tomonoura Onsen (Hiroshima) This onsen ryokan is located at Tomonoura, which is a port town known as the inspiration for Ponyo, a famous animated film by Studio Ghibli. Each guest room comes with a wood deck and a private open-air onsen bath that face the expansive ocean. There are also two sea-facing rental open-air baths outside the rooms for private use. Guests here can enjoy spa hopping at two nearby onsen accommodations of the same group, called Hotel Ofutei and Keishokan Sazanamitei. As to dining, you can eat authentic Japanese meals making use of seafood from the nearby waters, like red seabream and abalone, while looking at the fabulous view of the sea.

description: Book Hotel Ryokan Ayunosato in Hitoyoshi Onsen (Kumamoto) Located in a basin surrounded by the Kyushu Mountains, this ryokan stands next to the Kuma River, one of the three most rapid rivers of Japan. Its luxurious guest rooms are popular, with private open-air onsen baths and a great view of the river and the ruined Hitoyoshi Castle. Endowed with its own hot spring source said to promote beautiful skin, the ryokan offers a variety of hot spring experiences including separate male/female large public baths and drinkable hot spring water. Dining is also excellent, with creative kaiseki meals which are a fusion of Japanese and western-style food specially prepared by the head chef, and Kuma Shochu, a type of distilled spirit indigenous to the drainage area of the Kuma River.

description: Book Iki Retreat Kairi Murakami in Iki Island Onsen (Nagasaki) Situated on the Iki Island, about an hours ferry ride from Fukuoka, all guest rooms of this ryokan offer an oceanfront view and come with private open-air onsen baths. You can soak in the hot spring while gazing at the serene and ever-changing seascape all day long. Delicious food carefully prepared from a wide variety of ingredients, including fresh seafood, can be savoured in different styles like kaiseki and teppanyaki. The ryokan also provides a pairing service of food and shochu, a Japanese distilled liquor, as Iki Island is said to be the birthplace of barley shochu in Japan.

There are several types of hot springs including rental open-air baths outside the rooms for private use, gender-segregated large public baths, and others. This ryokan lies adjacent to the famous Kitamuki Kannon Temple and the Joraku-ji Temple. Many other Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples are also located in the nearby area.

name: Ryokan Shinsen
tags: ['Rooms with private open-air baths', 'Kyushu & Okinawa Region', 'Miyazaki', 'Takachiho Onsen', 'Kumamoto (Kumamoto Airport)']
description: Book Ryokan Shinsen in Takachiho Onsen (Miyazaki) At this ryokan, located about 8 minutes by car from the Takachiho Gorge, traditional elements including buildings with tatami-matted flooring and beautiful Japanese gardens create a refined Japanese ambiance. Despite the absence of a real hot spring, all rooms come with their own unique baths, such as open-air baths facing a large garden, or open-air baths in a separate tsubo-niwa (a type of very small, independent garden in Japan). Both dinner and breakfast are authentic Japanese kaiseki meals served in private dining rooms. Although a genuine hot spring is lacking, this ryokan is worthy of mention not only for its proximity to famous tourist attractions, but also because artistic baths designed to make you feel like youre actually soaking in a hot spring are available in all guest rooms.

All 15 guest rooms are in the Japanese architectural style of sukiya-zukuri, and have their own onsens. Although the tastes and indoor layout are different from one room to another, all rooms provide a romantic setting, with the scenery of a beautiful Japanese garden and an undeveloped woodland area near a village. description: Book Tofuya Resort & Spa-Izu in Shuzenji Onsen (Shizuoka) Guest rooms, restaurants and onsens are scattered all over this Japanese resort ryokans 119,000-square-metre large premises. A limpid stream also runs through the ryokans property. All 30 guest rooms, except 3 rooms that do not have bathtubs, have hot spring water supply, and are divided into several different types including washitsu (traditional Japanese tatami rooms), wa-yo-shitsu (Japanese-western rooms), yoshitsu (western-style rooms) and others. description: Book Mt. Resort Unzen Kyushu Hotel in Unzen Onsen (Nagasaki) It is an adult-oriented resort hotel transformed from an old hotel established in 1917 and opened in May 2018. Instead of the large public bath, which was eliminated in the renovation, all 25 guest rooms are installed with private onsen baths. Guest rooms are divided into two types, the Accommodation Building and the detached rooms. The 21 rooms in the Accommodation Building have an area of 60 square metres or larger, face the Unzen Jigoku and command great views, and have semi-open-air baths and terraces. On the other hand, the four detached rooms have an area of 90 square metres or larger, and have both semi-open-air and open-air baths. Meals are mainly western food, which guests of the Accommodation Building have at a restaurant with a causal atmosphere. Detached room guests can enjoy upgraded food at an exclusive and private dining room. The top floor of the Accommodation Building has a lounge exclusive to the hotels guests which offer stunning views and free drinks.

Gender-segregated large public scenic baths, open-air scenic baths, and a rental bath outside the rooms for private use are also available. tags: ['Rooms with private open-air baths', 'Rental hot spring baths for private use', 'Sea view', 'Hiroshima Chugoku Region', 'Hiroshima', 'Tomonoura Onsen', 'Hiroshima (Hiroshima Airport)']
description: Book Keishokan Sazanamitei in Tomonoura Onsen (Hiroshima) This purely Japanese-style onsen ryokan is located at Tomonoura, which is a port town known as the inspiration for Ponyo, a famous animated film by Studio Ghibli. All the 26 guest rooms, some in the Honkan (main building) and some in the Bekkan (annex), are washitsu (traditional Japanese-style rooms). Seven rooms come with open-air hot spring baths, four of which face the sea and three face the garden. In the gender-segregated large public onsen baths, there is a boat-shaped open-air bath and a large cypress barrel bath, and both of them command a spectacular view of the expansive ocean. Two rental baths outside the rooms for private use are also available. Guests here can enjoy spa hopping at a nearby onsen accommodation of the same group called Hotel Ofutei. It is just a five-minute walk from Keishokan Sazanamitei. As to dining, you can eat authentic Japanese meals making use of seafood from the nearby waters, such as red seabream which is a specialty of Tomonoura, at a cabin restaurant.

description: Book Momijiya Bekkan Kawa no Iori in Kyoto Takao Onsen Despite its convenient location that can be accessed from the Kyoto Station by train and taxi in 20 minutes, this folk-style ryokan is situated in a quiet and picturesque place called Takao, which is famous for its beautiful streams, greenery, fireflies, autumn leaves, and other rich natural resources. You have to cross a suspension bridge in order to get to the ryokan, which is also a distinctive characteristic. It has six guest rooms equipped with open-air baths, including two detached guest rooms and four other rooms. Gender-segregated semi-open-air baths and a rental bath outside the rooms for private use are also available. In summer, you can have dinner at kawadoko, a special type of Japanese-style restaurant where the floor is placed besides a river, while enjoying services provided by maikos (apprentice geishas).

description: Book Yunosuke-no-yado Chorakuen in Izumo-Tamatsukuri Onsen (Shimane) Founded in 1868, this ryokan has a long history and tradition. All guest rooms come with private hot spring baths. Its surroundings are car-free, providing a serene environment deep in the heart of nature. The authentic French cuisine served for dinner is also popular. Apart from the baths in each guest rooms, you can also enjoy onsen at the large public baths complete with open-air baths, and rental baths located outside the guest rooms for private use, making this hotel an ideal place for healing your body after a day of vigorous hiking or mountain climbing.
